Review title: It's difficult to handle the fatal mistakes of the past, but the movie teaches us...
Review_body:
Almira Biss****
The name of the movie "Spring, Summer, Autumn, and... Spring" defines one of the key ideas embodied in the plot of the work. The recurrence of life being the main idea of the movie, connects other concepts engaged in Buddhism, such as reincarnation, Samsara, and Dharma. Although these ideas were not clearly stated through verbal way, it can be seen that the scenes definitely convey the audience the feelings of characters by their actions and surroundings. The very first scene (5:10) of the picture painted on the Master's boat gives us the basic thought about the correspondence between the phenomenon of recurrence and the name of the film. The picture on the boat depicted a giant man, carrying a lotus, which in its turn carried a little man praying inside of it. The implied meaning of the scene which accidentally can be noticed by the attentive ones, draws the attention to the same idea and highlights it. This work was intended to demonstrate the existential thought of cyclicality by focusing its audience on the changes of seasons, birth and death, mistakes and redemption.
The story of a Master and his student is central in tangling these ideas, thereby revealing us the tenets of Buddhism.Throughout the seasonal and spiritual changes the background remain fixed. A deep valley with a peaceful lake and the floating temple. The exotic forest isolating a Master from idleness of the outer world..., Although remaining the same, the location transforms as a new season comes, which symbolizes another shift in personal vision of the main character. As the time flies, each season epitomize same person with different views, which we can attribute to the particular season. In the first scenes it is the spring. The time of renewal and growth, the time of innocence. The nature is young and childish, and so is the student of a Master. Naive and stupid, he follows his heart without understanding the point of his actions. The boy ties a thread to a fish, a frog, and finally to a snake. The Master silently observes the actions of his pupil. After all, he treats the child with the same, tying the thread with a stone to his back. The scene that reveals the stupidity of a child and sage mind of the Master can be interpreted very differently. However, the duality of the scene is not a mistake, but the versatility of life. At the first, the Master can be seen as the God, or Karma, or Universe, etc. Whatever person believes, there is the universal law in the face of such Master that will observe your deeds and penalize for the bad ones. Boomerang or cyclicality is a universal principle here, and the Master teaches the young to understand that. Secondly, it can be seen that in comparison with a mature pupil seen further in the movie, if you're a child, you still have a chance to grow up morally without being penalized for the mistakes, as the adult would have been. Adults are not innocent, even though they still can be stupid and have childish mind. Developing this idea further, it can be said that although everyone can grow morally, but the strikes for mistakes remain, as it leads people to realization of their deeds...Summer. The time of flourishing nature and flourishing youth. The temper and energy of a young man that been alone all this time, were finally realized when he met the lady brought to the Master one day. Being unable to restrain his physical desire, young man neglects the principles taught and steps over the lines, without using the entries, which importance can be noticed since the first sight at the movie (42:45 min). The doors or gateways are symbolical in Buddhism, and neglecting this ritual, young Buddhist implied the superiority of natural desire over life principles in temple. He secretly allows his beloved one to sit on the stone statue, which before was not allowed (43:13 min). His actions apparently reveal that he chooses "normal" life over sacral service, and entailing the silent furriness of the Master, he escapes to pursue his love. Before he escapes, the Master tells him the following:"the desire to possess awakens the intent to murder"
(47:41 min)
By saying these words, the Teacher warned his pupil to refrain from desires, as such possession blinds people and leads them to sinful things. You cannot control others but rather they will control you, as you give them your everything. It's better to chase your inner peace and harmony. The pupil did not understand it.Autumn. Nature fades away. Death of living creatures. The decline of life energy. The Master finds out what happened to his pupil after he accidentally saw the excerpt of newspaper with his portrait. He understood that the student will be back very soon. The flat colors of autumn epitomize the dark mind of a wanderer. The Master physically punishes him for murder, as it happened since the pupil forgot about the sacral beginning of his life and became ignorant. The Master commits suicide, as he realizes the mistake he made. He could not raise the follower, the next master.
This scene describes the dark side of the life circle. As the life continues, the mistakes, sometimes fatal, are inescapable, if people will not follow some principles. However, as the lessons taught in Spring season, everyone still has a hope to grow morally. The Master, before he dies, teaches the last lesson to his pupil, by making him carving the symbols with the knife. The last lesson was a last spark in the dark mind, which started thinking recalling past experience.
The shining ice and snow in the winter embodies purification and pure mind. As the pupil comes back to deep valley, he finds a snake in the clothes of his Master. That reminds us of reincarnation; as the snake keeps living with him as if they used to live together before, and does not distract anyone, the symbolic meaning becomes clear. The snake is a symbol of wisdom, and it's interesting parallel with the Master that left as human, but came back as snake. As the winter was going to end, the woman brings her child, which she could not keep with her. That apparently brings us to the logical beginning of the story of the Master and his pupil. As the woman escapes, she drowned in the lake, accidentally stepping into the hole. The new Master walks out and instead of woman he finds the Buddha statue. This symbol of coming back to sacral traditions means the acceptance of a new Master. The last gesture that can be seen as a gesture of respect and tribute to dead Master, can be seen the scene, where his former pupil does the same punishment to himself as in childhood (1:32:36). Since this moment he realizes his role in the world.
Spring. A new pupil plays with fish, making it eat stones and sees how it drowns. The turn comes to frog, and finally to a snake. Is he going to repeat the Master's lifelong cycle?After watching that movie which idea was the inevitable cyclicality, there's one thought that I believe stuck in minds of people. If the circle is infinite, can it be escapable? Yes and no. The author leaves us with the same question, as the end of the movie remains open. Who knew, whether this pupil is going to repeat the fate of his teacher, or the teacher will save him from his mistakes...
Whatever the answer is, it happened before, it happens, and it will repeat itself...

Review title: so relevant - so powerful - opens your mind
Review_body:
Watching this film and thinking about it afterwards was what made me sign up here and write this review. I've never written one before. This is only what I got from it - I'm sure it holds a thousand messages.
There are very few words spoken, and what is said therefore holds great importance. One of the first things the master says is that the boy will carry the weight of the dead animals throughout his life. And he does. Then the master says that part about lust leading to possession leading to murder. And he does. I think the master kills himself because he realizes his own responsibility in the boys life: the way his words have the power to create, and how they perhaps got the boy into jail. I'm not a Buddhist but suicide is a huge deal and I'm sure it is in Buddhism too. Or maybe he wanted to free the boy of himself. He did have creative powers: we saw him will the boat to come to him, or to stop. And then, once out of prison, the "boy" realizes he has to become a master himself to a new boy. But he understands The Cycle and wants to get rid of it as well as The Weight. So he takes it all as far as he can get it from the house but still within view as a reminder. And then is free to teach the new boy, and be master himself. And when the new boy goes torturing animals, he is no longer there, like the original master was, watching over the new boy's shoulder. And so the cycle is broken.
The message I got from this film is that as any figure of authority, one needs to really really deeply think about their own responsibility, and scrutinize the power they have.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and SpringThis South Korean film directed by Kim Ki-Duk metaphorically represents the life of a Buddhist monk and his disciple in the center of the lake. The location of the lake is a remote area from civilization, makes it a perfect place to attain soul calmness and deep meditation. The main story of the film was divided into 5 parts, each assigned with the season, as seen from the film's title. The very first Spring corresponds to innocent childhood, summer depicted as young adulthood, the feeling of love, and its subsequent conversion to lust and anger. Continuing in the same manner, fall corresponds to adulthood errors, where the former disciple murdered his wife on the emotional bases and subsequent perception of those errors as they are. Finally, winter was a time of awareness, which depicted in the film by a returning student to his previous master's hermitage. What I found peculiar and intriguing about "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring" was the absence of conversational dialogue between the main characters or any kind of explanation from the filmmakers during the film, despite, the story itself attract and acknowledge viewer into the meaning and cultural traditions performed in the film. Based on the symbolics, prayer, and activities they performed, it is obviously seen that they are followers of the Mahayana Buddhism branch, where people used to pray upon Buddha. Coming up to the main point, there were lots of cultural and metaphorical elements used, such as a boat that automatically returns to master, swiftly changing animals with the change fo season, and the weirdest one was gluing stickers to face when the master burned himself on the boat. However, among all of these signs, the notions mostly related to course material were the depiction of karma and samsara.
Karma is the belief that any action in the present inevitably provokes an echo-like response in the future. Either negative or positive, depending on the nature of the deed itself. In this particular case, karma was represented in the film by the childhood action of the boy, when he bound a fish to the stone via rope, then repeated the same action with the frog and snake. Despite the obvious suffering of these animals, observed scenes made the boy laugh. At this very moment, his Master observed a young student from behind. To teach him a lesson master bound his young disciple to the heavy stone that night and ordered him to find and free those animals if he wants to take off the stone from his back. Along with this, the following phrase was said by his master: "If one of them has died, you will always carry that stone in your heart". However, when the child found fish and snake, they were already dead. Carrying this in mind, the last scenes from the film should be discussed to have a whole picture. In the season of Winter, man (previously disciple) carried the statue of meditating Buddha to the peak of a nearby mountain by bounding himself to huge and heavy stone. At this moment, previously scenes of suffering animals were inserted by filmmakers, which in my opinion was a representation of karma. So the action he made in childhood returned to him as his own anchor, both physically and metaphorically.
Next, samsara is the Buddhist or even Hinduism term to describe the endless and beginningless chain of lives, where each and every person must rebirth after his death until attaining the state of nirvana. This is the main goal of Buddhist practitioners, to attain nirvana to escape the endless life chain, and dissolve oneself within the universe level. The samsara was depicted in the final part of the film, where the newly arrived disciple of a monk, repeated almost exactly the same animal bullying actions with fish, frog, and snake. Also at the moment when the monk burned himself and ceased to exist, the small snake appeared beneath the boat. This can be interpreted by Buddha's (Siddhartha Gautama) approach toward the nature of the soul as a flow of the river. And when the monk has died, his appearance simply changed or acquired another form. In other words, errors of the past are made to make correct conclusions in the future, in the same manner, life someone lives in the past, define the status and flow of the next rebirth.
Summing up all points, the film "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring" is a mixture of both well-written scenario and Asian minimalistic art style, because of the lack of excessive speech, complex actions, or transition of location. Despite the fact that all details were kept simple, this did not negatively reflect on the film quality. The film combined a physical representation of a monk and his disciple's life path, along with a metaphorical depiction of ideas. From the numerous symbolics and traditions, the idea of karma and samsara was discussed in this review, which in my opinion gives a solid explanation, why Buddhist monks adhere to this kind of lifestyle and the essence of Buddhism as a religion.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring is an aesthetically pleasing work with a great soundtrack to complement the stunning visuals. The scene of the protagonist's frosty ascent onto a hill with the attached stone that symbolizes the weight of all the hardships and suffering the monk has caused to himself and others, which is accompanied the traditional Korean song Jeongseon Arirang performed by Kim Young Im, is a cinematic masterpiece. In general, the rural setting and slow pacing of the plot during each season make the occurring events seem timeless, which creates a tranquil feeling that eases the mind. Bar the masterful directing itself, much of this feeling has to do with Buddhist symbolism, which is unsurprisingly plentiful in this movie. This review will discuss such recurring Buddhist themes in the movie, particularly the cyclicality of life.To start from the metaphorical imagery of the film, the main theme is that of the cyclicality of life - a motif that is essential in both Hinduism and Buddhism, which is a shramana religion - that is, an offshoot of Hinduism. Time passes in cycles, and history always repeats itself. We are shown this circularity through the life of our protagonist, who is a man that spends his childhood in a small Buddhist monastery in the middle of a lake under the guidance of his teacher - a bodhisattva who is referred to as the "wise one". The protagonist's life - from childhood until old age - is presented in the course of five seasons: spring, summer, fall, winter and spring once again, which represents the renewal of the limitless cycle. The four seasons interchange every year regardless of what era it is - this cycle had been present well before human beings emerged, and will persist long after humankind is gone. Hence, they symbolize infinity and repetition - the endless cycle of birth, death, rebirth and suffering - the concept of samsara - to which humans are subjected unless they are liberated from this physical realm by achieving Nirvana through the Noble Eightfold Path.This repetition is reflected not solely in the fact that the film begins and ends in spring - the very scenes on the screen are identical. In the beginning, the carefree young protagonist torments animals - he plays with a fish, a frog and a snake by attaching a stone to them and considers the results quite amusing. Children may do such things in real life because they do not yet understand the concept of pain and suffering. The main character's mentor teaches the child that lesson of empathy and karma by attaching a large stone to him as well and making him find and release the animals. It is revealed that the fish and the snake died while the frog survived. In the very end of the movie, we are shown a similar scene with the new boy, the student of our matured protagonist, who torments the same three animals by shoving a stone into their mouths. This is symbolic of the fate of human beings in samsara - doomed to repeat the same mistakes again and again.Another important feature of the movie is the theme of Buddhist monasticism, particularly celibacy. Of course, Buddhist monks are supposed to renounce everything materialistic in order to achieve the spiritual bliss. Hence, they must renounce wealth, alcohol, sex, father no children, and so on - anything that may lead their journey towards Nirvana astray. Our protagonist breaks this rule by falling in love in with the sick girl and eventually choosing to flee the monastery and live with her. What the main character at that point did not understand, however, is that his love was doomed. According to the main principles of Buddhism (The Four Noble Truths), life is full of suffering - the concept of dunkha. The root of all suffering is craving - people have carnal, material desires that can never be fully satisfied, which is the notion of trishna. In order to overcome suffering, one must overcome their desires and relinquish the earthly by following the Eightfold Noble Path. Therefore, because the protagonist wanted the girl and lusted after her body and love in general, his craving inevitably led to suffering.The protagonist's teacher, on the other hand, that realizes how fleeting the material world is. Enlightened, he possesses prajna - a state of mind, the ability to see the true nature of reality, which is a mere abstraction of ties and relations in our minds. This concept is somewhat reminiscent of Plato's cave and the Chariot allegory, which postulate the notion that ordinary human beings are not able to grasp the true Form of things and can only see mere shadows. This emptiness of all phenomena that the Master recognizes is called shunyata. Consequently, the monk understands that the protagonist's romance with the girl is merely evanescent. He warns his student, "Lust awakens the desire to possess. And that awakens the intent to murder" (Kim Ki-duk, 2003) - foreboding the impending suffering. A little bit later, the protagonist tells his new girlfriend that he becomes crazy when he cannot see her - proving his obsession with this lust, which is discouraged in Buddhism, especially for those who strive to be a monk. The mentor's prediction becomes true, for years after the main character murders his girlfriend-wife for alleged infidelity and comes back to the monastery in a fury of rage. The loss of his love may also be attributed to the fish and the snake he killed earlier in the movie - the stone that he had to carry in his heart for the rest of his life, which is connected to the concept of karma. Only after letting go of his anger by carving out the Heart Sutra, serving his prison sentence and returning to the monastery once again, the protagonist resumes training and finally liberates himself from carnal desires and becomes a bonafide monk.After which the cycle begins anew and the time comes for our protagonist to be the mentor and show his protégé the path towards liberation - the Nirvana.

Review title: Some thoughts about Buddhist teaching in the movie
Review_body:
First of all, I would like to say that after watching this movie to write a review straight away is not so easy as for many other movies people can do. This movie is deep and touching so that it leaves behind many thoughts to think about. It took me around two days to fully understand the movie. Here, I would like to concentrate on some aspects of Buddhist teachings and symbols appeared in the movie.Movie begins as the door with the picture of two muscle-rich men and the scenery of a floating monastery in the middle of the lake. The door stands on itself without any walls around and acts as the entrance to the land from the lake. The other door without walls is in the monastery in the space between sleeping and praying areas. I believe the door symbolizes division of two places as sacred and profound. Also, it shows how people follow traditions and customs as the act of going through the door even if there are no walls there. On the summer part of the movie adolescent monk in the night approaches the girl forgetting to enter to her space through the door. In this way, he disobeyed the Buddhism precept of refraining from sexual misconduct.There is another percept of Buddhism which tells not to harm living creatures. In the first spring, boy monk tied three animals to stones which in turn caused death of two animals. Older monk taught him a lesson by making the boy to carry a stone himself. In this part, we can see not only animal liberation of Buddhism, but also instant karma reached the boy. In the next spring, man carries Buddha statue along with the stone tied up to his belly in order to clear his karma the past sins his done to dead animals last spring. When he brings Buddha on the top he finds himself a redemption and freedom from his sins.
Animals play an important role in the house too. During different periods of time we can see different pets in the monastery, this presence indirectly relates to different stages of younger monk and shows how Buddhism teaches us to share our space with others since we cannot own any property by ourselves.Older monk had very interesting attitude towards the boy. He did not stop the boy hurting the animals though he was observing him secretly. Instead he just taught him a lesson which I understood as giving a direction of right behavior. Older monk did not stop him from boy chasing after the girl, he was just observing. The reason for that I believe is that life goes as it is. In Buddhist religion people are born pure, they make mistakes and they suffer, but most importantly they must learn from the past. Furthermore, older monk taught him Dhamma in fall, which was about overcoming dissatisfaction and sufferings.Perception of life, body, and soul in Buddhist teachings is something special. We can see this phenomena through death of older monk in the winter. Firstly, he felt gradually that his time has come and prepares. He has left all his belongings in the house and did his cremation outside on the boat, because according to the Buddhist teachings we are just guests in nature around us, in the house, and in our own body, so everything will be there after we die. When he sets himself on fire he feels nothing because he could separate his body and his soul during his meditation and could attain enlightenment. After his death grown boy monk finds white little stones (Sarira) on the place of the self-cremation. White stones or Sariras are left behind after Buddhist spiritual masters, which means that older monk has attained Nirvana. Adult monk wraps Sarira in red tissue and put in the forehead in the ice Buddha statue. This is another belief when tissue is freely floating around the soul has completely gone.In the next spring, man carries Buddha statue along with the stone tied up to his belly in order to be free from the past sins his done to dead animals last spring. When he brings Buddha on the top he finds himself a redemption.By the end of the movie we can observe that life goes in a circular manner, just like Buddhism notion of Samsara. Adult monk taught himself the martial arts and diligent praying. One day woman with her face covered leaves her little baby to the monk. And in the next spring we can see grown boy just like the monk was at the beginning of the movie. At this point viewer can notice clearly how life goes the same way only the people are changing. The fact that names of the characters are not given suggests that it does not matter in a life cycle. This is what Samsara, or wheel of life can teach us.Director of the movie Ki-duk Kim played the role of adult monk and did it, in my humble opinion, perfectly. From the technical view, the major pearl of this movie is the choice of scenery and shooting angles. Despite the shooting was done at the same location and the cast was limited, change of seasons and development of the main characters made this movie very catching and appealing to watch. I would suggest this movie to watch for anyone interested in Buddhism religion or for those who seek some mental pabulum.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
The "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring" masterfully reflects some major aspects of Mahayana Buddhism teachings through serene depictions of the Buddhist monk life. We are introduced to the ideas of karma, samsara, and the role of desire in our sufferings, as well as we could observe many minor details and cultural references. The symbolism in the movie as in the case of changing animals with each season tells the story more vividly than any dialogue could have. So, let us review how Kim Ki Duk reflects on the aspects of Buddhism through his movie.
Throughout the movie, the main topic that we can observe is the Buddhist idea of samsara and karmic debt. The movie follows the main character from his youth to the point when he himself has a pupil, and each season represents the critical points of his life. It becomes especially apparent to the end of the movie in the winter and spring seasons that the movie reflects samsara and the cyclical nature of things. In the following spring, his pupil repeats his master's youth actions with stones and animals but in a slightly different manner. It might hint that his pupil is bound to repeat the previous monk's path while accumulating and releasing karmic debt in a different manner. Also, in fall, when the elder monk self-immolates we can see tears in his eyes, it is not that clear whether he feels compassion for his pupil or that it might be an indication that he himself has a karmic debt but tears more likely to represent that elder monk is still in the cycle. So, as we can see the movie has masterfully illustrated the cyclical nature of life and samsara.
Another main aspect of the movie is the topic of karmic debt that might be depicted in the form of stone. When the monk tortured animals, his teacher tied a stone to him similar to his tortures which could be metaphorical to the karmic debt that makes an individual's path to nirvana burdensome. This idea is facilitated in the winter when the main character travels to the top of the mountain with the statue of Buddha and stone tied to him, indicating how his path to nirvana is burdened by his past deeds. The statues of the Buddha are also quite symbolic and might indicate the body of knowledge about the path. For instance, when he escapes following the girl, he brings with himself a rooster and a stone statue of Buddha, which might tell that despite he is led by his desire, the knowledge given by his master lies like a burden in his heart. Returning the statue to its place was a sign of returning to the path. In winter, while the statue of Buddha equally burdened his path to the top of the mount as a stone tied to his body, it was also the whole meaning of his trip, to begin with, and might symbolize the significance of wisdom to obtain nirvana. Another interesting observation is the monk's attitude to the path and girl reflected by the haetae, stone lions, so if at first, he prohibited her to sit on them, later he encouraged it. So, it is quite intriguing how the author managed to use stone and statues to reflect upon karmic debt or to tell about the journey of the monk.
Finally, we have to look at the Buddhist concept of three poisons that keep individuals inside samsara, which are anger, attachment, and ignorance. The plot of the movie is focused on two of the poisons that are attachment and anger. Respectively, we have scenes with rooster and snake, which are the symbols for these poisons. The central quote of the movie that "desire to possess leads to the intent to murder", ties attachment and aversion together. It also reflects one of the Four Noble Truths of Buddhist teachings that sufferings are caused by desires. Also, we have a scene when the master makes the main character to carve Prajnaparamita sutra, which perfectly summarizes the plot. Sutra states that there is no suffering or desire since everything is in the void state. We can see how an understanding of the sutra helped him to regain inner peace. So, the monk's affection towards woman, which followed by her murder, not only reflects on the Four Noble Truth that sufferings are caused by desires but also illustrates his path to wisdom.
Overall, the "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring" managed to introduce the viewer through scenery and symbols to the main aspects of the Mahayana Buddhist teachings. Karmic debt, samsara, and the emptiness of existence are conveyed through various symbols without the use of direct dialogues. While some symbols as the rooster are more apparent, the meaning behind others as tears during self-immolation could be debatable. It could be concluded that Kim Ki Duk not only created a film that helps us to observe the main aspects of Buddhism but also to raise questions about our life paths.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: The South Korean film "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter ... and Spring" directed by Kim Ki-Duk not only creates the unique atmosphere of the floating temple that helps to feel the spirit of Buddhism but also delivers several important messages in the framework of Buddhist religious beliefs. The beautiful setting of the films in terms of dense forest, mountainous terrain, and lakes transmits calmness and unity with nature. While a stone statue of a Buddha on the top of a mountain that appears several times in the frame, as it were, reminds of the essence of a Buddha around us and in our lives. Along with the importance of the environment and landscape, the film also conveys several important ideas about Buddhism. The major Buddhist ideas that film represents are the wheel of life concept, monk's teaching, and the experience of the monk himself. The film as the whole piece transmits the idea of the wheel of life and helps to understand how life is the infinite circle. Monk's teaching of the boy through his lessons helps to understand basic concepts and wises of Buddhism such as karma or no harm for others. While through the monk's life we can understand the pass of the Buddhist monks to achieve liberation. In this review, I would like to focus on these three major concepts of the film that seem for me as the representation of Buddhist beliefs and that helped me to see and understand the religion deeper.The title of the film and how the plot is presented already contains an important message from Buddhism. Years in the film are presented in the form of seasons, which, as everyone knows, are repeated from year to year, so that after winter there will be another spring and the cycle never ends. The same as the endless wheel of life in which one life ends up being reborn in another form. This concept of reincarnation is one of the majors in Buddhist religious beliefs. When a monk dies or, more precisely, achieves liberation, an already grown boy comes to his place, who at one time was a student of a monk, and now, having taken his place, he is a teacher for the child. The circle has closed, spring has come again, which represents how the wheel of life continues to move forward. These two ideas of the wheel of life and reincarnation are best at presenting the important Buddhist beliefs since the desire of the true Buddhist is to escape samsara while others remain in the wheel and their soul continues to live the next life. I think the general form of the film and the story helped to depict these important notions.Other important wises of Buddhism can be understood from the presented relations between the old monk and the boy. Monk teaches the boy lessons based on practical experience rather than theoretical ideas. So that when the boy tortures animals and the next day finds the stone roped to his back he and the viewers themselves can understand the meaning of the karma and the wise principle of "no harm to any living being". By the power of the monk's lesson comes the understanding of the Buddhist pearls of wisdom. The film is not rich for long dialogues but when the monk says something his words contain important thoughts through which Buddhism can be understood. Such that "you will carry the stone in your heart for the rest of your life" as a response to the boy if he finds the tortured animals dead or "lust awakens the desire to possess which leads to intent to murder" when the boy starts sexual relations with the girl. Through these words, we can understand why Buddhists promote no harm to others and dismissal from sexual relations. All these words and depicted lessons for the boy help to understand the principles that form a basis for the monk and thus Buddhist religion in general.And finally, regarding the image of the monk presented in the film we can understand more about their path in attaining enlightenment. As in Buddhist societies, monks are highly respected and supported people who can attain nirvana it is important to understand how they live and what path follow. The monk in the film possess not many belongings, lives in the distant temple surrounded by water and other nature. His life does not include any entertainment or other benefits that ordinary people can enjoy. This can be understood by one of the Nobel truths of Buddhism when one can overcome suffering by abandoning cravings and passions that cause these sufferings. We see his life focused on praying, teaching the boy, and helping other people through Buddhist religious principles. So that when the girl comes to him, he helps her soul and body to recover with praying and herbs. I see the monk as a central figure in the story as he was the one who wanted to help the boy attain the right views and thought, direct him on the Noble Path through the Buddhist religion. So that in the end the boy himself became the monk and was ready to teach another boy all he knew from his life and lessons of the monk.In conclusion, I regard this film not only as of the cinematic art but as the illustrative example of some ideas presented in the Buddhist religion. From the characters and story presented in the movie, the viewer can grasp the way of monk's life, their principles, and some basic concept as samsara or karma.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
After watching this movie, I was left with many questions that did not let me write anything about the movie until I dug deeper into my thoughts around it. First, I tried to absorb everything in before connecting it to things I recently learned from the course. I think that the movie was made so well that even without any knowledge about Buddhist traditions, I would have still understood the message: karma always follows the person. Positive actions lead to beneficial results, whereas negative actions lead to unwanted consequences. In this review, I will discuss how "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter and... Spring" demonstrates the Buddhist belief system, particularly, its aspects such as anatman, karma, samsara, upaya, and karuna.
First, the movie starts with a beautiful scene of a monastery floating on the lake. There are a Buddha's figure, candles, and other tools used for praying and rituals. It is clear that the monastery is a special place. According to Eliade, religion is based on the division between the sacred space and the profane space. (Eliade, 1973) In this movie, monastery implies a hierophany, the manifestation of sacred. The set it a sacred place, thus, the movie gives a full picture of the Buddhist religion and its values.
The first season depicted in a movie is spring, where the little boy gets his first lessons from the master. The master teaches the boy to appreciate other beings' lives as your own and punishes the boy for misbehaving and demonstrating egoism. I would say that this lesson is an example of Karuna, which is a limitless compassion to all beings. It helps to overcome cravings by cultivating altruism. (Lecture on Mahayana Buddhism)
Another lesson master tried to give to the disciple is anatman. According to lecture, anatman is a belief that soul is an unstable and ever changing phenomenon. In "summer," the teen disciple falls a victim of lust and desire to possess. The master warns him that "lust leads to desire for possession, and possession leads to murder." It is implied that soul is not stable, so you cannot possess anyone. The desire to do so is contrary to Buddhist beliefs and karma would punish the boy for that.
There is also a clear demonstration of four noble truths.
1. Life is full of sufferings. Buddhists recognize suffering beyond its physical appearance. For instance, in the movie, the master says that when the girl finds peace in her soul, her body would return to health. When he learns about the intimate relationships between the young monarch and the girl, he calmly states that if it was a medicine, then it was meant to be. However, he does not let them continue their romance since pleasure is also considered a suffering. It leads to the dependence on the partner, which causes dissatisfaction since possession is not real.
2. The root of sufferings are cravings. In the movie, the young monarch's desire for pleasure caused a lot of suffering such as anxiety, anger and jealousy.
3. To overcome sufferings one should overcome cravings. 4. To achieve this, one should follow the Eightfold Noble Path. The young monarch achieves the right state of mind only when he starts following the Eightfold Noble Path (gaining better understanding of the life, leading a lifestyle that cleans the karma and practicing meditation.) (Lecture on the early Buddhism)
Since I learned it was a Korean movie, I have tried to figure out which Buddhist tradition it upholds to. I supposed that it was a Mahayana Buddhism since Korea was one of the main Mahayana Buddhist branches due to lecture on Mahayana Buddhism. While watching the movie, I got surer of it. As it was already mentioned before, there is Karuna, which is one of the four key Mahayana concepts. Tantra is another practice demonstrated in a movie that helped to categorize it as a Mahayana Buddhism. According to lecture, tantra is "an advanced practice for attaining enlightenment integrating meditative, physical, and psychic exercises", (Lecture on Mahayana Buddhism) which helps to attain Nirvana. In season "winter," the monarch progresses his spirituality by doing some physical exercises and training his body. We can see that his body is fit and his soul is nourished. Tantra can also be a considered a part of Upaya, which is another key Mahayana concept.
Finally, how do all of the concepts above are connected to samsara and karma? Samsara is a wheel of life, the round of rebirths. (Spiro, 1966, p. 1169) Karma is the net balance of one's merits and demerits, (Spiro, 1966, p. 1169) which means that what one does in their life affects the future existence of the soul. In order not to make mistakes and have good karma, one should understand the four noble truths and practice upaya and karuna. When the boy completes the sutras in the end of the movie, he finally realizes that life is a suffering and everything is impermanent. The soul changes just like the seasons in the movie: spring, summer, fall, winter and spring again. So, the young monarch turns into a master by going through redemption and liberating his soul from suffering.

Review_body:
Movie Review on "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter and... Spring"
The movie about Buddhism was filmed by South Korea. It is about the endless circulation of life, the teacher continues in student. Even for the person, who have never heard of it, it will be pretty clear what this religion is about. The name itself signals on the main idea - circulation of life. The years like seasons.
It highlights the main points - 4 Noble truths or Basic formula of the religion: suffering, the cause of suffering, the end of suffering, the path of achieving the end of it. All of these truths were shown in the movie step by step.
The truth of suffering is shown through the whole movie, from the beginning till the end. It starts with the scene where a boy tortures a fish, a frog and a snake. He ties them to a stone and makes them suffer while laughing at them. The master doesn't clean after his student and doesn't lecture, instead, he allows him to make mistakes and suffer. He points his student a way to discover the life. The student feels guilty when he sees dead fish and snake, so he should now live with a stone in his heart - life is full of sufferings.
The next is the truth of the cause of suffering which are people's desires. It is clearly explained when the student meets the first woman and love in his life. The student gives in to feelings, lust and instincts. His cravings make him blind, emotional and uncontrollable. He lost his head and inner peace with the love and lust. In one of the scenes, at the very beginning when the girl just came to their hut in order to get some therapy, she sits in one of their sculptured stone which is precious for the master. The boy warns the girl that it is very important for the master. But then, we notice that he no more cares about these sculptured stones and lets his love to sit on it. So we can see how love, his desires blind him quickly.
Finally, he kills his wife because of his desires, lost of control and the master points out the philosophy of Buddhism: "sometimes we have to let go things we like". So, sometimes we have to let go people we cannot live without.
The wise master helps him with no words, but actions. He helps his student to restore his inner peace with "Prajnaparamita Sutra" - collection about forty texts. So the student cuts each character with the knife with which he killed his wife, and gets inner peace. So, the third truth about the end of the sufferings is here. In order to end the sufferings, one should end with his/her desires, cravings. And it is not about suicide, as the student tried to do with sticked character which means "shut, stop up", but to accept all your mistakes, have a life lesson and move on, no matter how difficult it is.
Finally, the fourth noble truth is about the path leading to the end of these sufferings. I think the film represents it with the coming back of the student from the jail or the death of the master. They truly found the inner peace inside, by following the Eightfold Noble Path: right views, thoughts, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, concentration. The millstone and the sculpture of Buddha represent the killings that he regrets about all of his life at the end. He carried this karma through all of his life and carried to the hill, finally sets free and finds the end of the sufferings.
The young boy at the beginning and the ending represents people. Good life is not achieved by having no bad thoughts, but by mastering your thoughts. By overpowering yourself and being better. Our behavior does not choose us, but we choose it. We choose whom we want to be, and only we can control ourselves. For some it is more difficult than for others, but it is possible to achieve the end of sufferings with following the Eightfold Noble Path. Everyone is born with the sin, and everyone has its own path to divinity. By showing the same boy at the end of the movie and the beginning, the movie shows the eternal cycle of human beings. The teacher continues in his or her student.
The movie shows the main points of the religion, such as the Four Noble Truths which is the main and basic formula of the religion. They show "Pajnaparamita Sutra" which helps a person to restore inner peace; that everyone has his/her own path of achieving the end of sufferings by two scenes: the boys who make animals suffer both at the beginning and at the end. The idea is one, but actions are different. Summarizing all of it, the movie explains the idea of Buddhism very effectively.

Review_body: The film is about the unusual life of the Buddhist monk, undergoing through consecutive stages of life and circumstances which he brings himself into. The main focus was on the concept of cause and effect relationship, which is known as the law of karma in the religious realm, shown in monk's actions. The peculiarity of the film is in it's details, with the help of which the author tries to show the various aspects of Buddhist religious tradition. In my opinion, the film's ability to represent the aspects of Buddhist religion through the contrast of the main protagonist's viewpoint of life and his master's viewpoint is demonstrated quite well.Life is full of sufferings. This is one of the points in the four Noble Truths in Buddha's Teachings and namely this concept is demonstrated in the film as the starting point in the life of the young monk. The film clearly shows the master's intention to make the student realize that he should be ready to bear the mental burden of his action's implications on himself and only himself. And not only a monk's wrong actions eventually bring him to the sufferings, but the pleasures as well. And one can see that this is illustrated by means of the teenage monk's psychological attachment to the girl, which eventually brings him into disappointment and horrible consequences. In contrast the master's viewpoint tells us about his vision as where he tells the boy to not follow his cravings as it will result in bad implications for him. So we can conclude from the Buddhism point of view the young monk is setting the seeds of his karma due to his ignorance of life's aspects.Secondly, the evolving consciousness of the monk will bear the seeds of karma set in his earlier life. For example, he can not simply finish his life after killing a person or an animal, where the intention was to show that he will live with that for the rest of his life and carry that 'stone' with him. So, during the rest of his life he always will get the 'prompts' about his deeds he has done.To conclude, one can see that the film clearly demonstrated the concepts of Buddhism to the viewer, where the main focus was to show the law of karma. Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter, and Spring showed us the Buddhist concept of continuity of life cycles and that to exit from these cycles one should get rid of all his cravings.

Review_body:
The film "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter and ... Spring" tells a story of a young Buddhist monk, whose lifetime lasts like the four seasons of nature. The boy goes through the periods of his life, along the way learning the valuable lessons and trying to achieve his inner peace. The boy's teacher leads him through the path of hardships and sufferings, and the boy comes back to his Master even after leaving him for some time. Throughout the plot many references to various Buddhist concepts can be seen, symbolically and in hidden meanings. The ending of the film also proposes an important idea of Buddhism about the infinite chain of lifetimes of the person - samsara.
The boyhood of a monk is shown in the film as spring - the symbolical beginning of life, traditional image of innocence and joy. In this period of his life the boy learns his first important lesson - that every living being should be treated as one would treat him-/herself. When the young monk tortures a fish, a frog and a snake by tying them to a stone, the Master does the same to the boy, making him endure what the tortured creatures have gone through. The Buddhist concept of karuna - compassion to all living beings - can be traced in this episode, when the teacher explains to his apprentice this lesson of life. Buddhism, like many other religions, propagates the non-violence practice, an idea which is also strongly present in this episode. Besides, the concept of upaya could be noticed here too, as the Master teaches the lesson through applying a technique fit for the young boy to understand it through experiencing the torture himself.
The next stage of life of the monk is the adolescence, which is compared to summer. In this period the boy discovers the worldly pleasures which are forbidden in the monastic lifestyle. Upon violating the celibacy, the boy is not punished by his teacher, who rather pronounces that it is just the way of nature. However, when the boy leaves the temple to follow his object of affection, he is warned by the Master of dangers of the passion and lust. This reflects the ideas of the Four Noble Truths of Buddhism, which state that the reasons of sufferings are our cravings and desires, and to overcome the pain it is necessary to overcome the cravings. The boy does not listen to the warnings of the teacher and leaves, led by his passion and desire.
The next episode of the man's life shows that the Master's words and, therefore, the Four Noble Truths were right. Before the boy left, the teacher told him that lust awakens desire to possess, and desire to possess leads to murder. The exact thing happened indeed, and the now young man came back to the temple, after killing his wife in flush of jealous anger. The Buddhist conception of Eightfold Noble Path teaches that one should maintain right views, thoughts and actions, to obtain the Four Noble Truths. However, the main character of the film is shown to divert from this path of righteousness despite his teachings, by submitting to his irrational feelings, which caused him to suffer and to commit crime. This is another valuable lesson that the monk, as well as the viewers learn from his life - that it is necessary to monitor one's thoughts and deeds and not to follow blindly the rush of feelings.
Another wise saying of the Master in the film states that sometimes it is needed let go of things we like. The monk learns this in the "autumn" of his life, after coming back to the temple. As he is tormented by anger, the teacher attempts to drive these negative feelings inside the man away, by making him do an exhausting task, which eventually brings peace to the man's soul. This is yet another illustration of the Buddhist idea of training to overcome the suffering. The man has calmly accepted his fate and voluntarily submitted himself to detectives who take him to prison. The central idea of Buddhism - training one's spirit and body to achieve the inner peace - is the focus of this episode of the film.
The winter shows that the monk is now a middle-aged man, who was freed from prison. He pays respect to his late Master and continues his monastic life in the temple, learning martial arts and training in severe conditions. The man's spirit has become strong and tough, and he is shown to achieve the most of his physical and psychological potential, thus overcoming all his fears and weaknesses. Once again, we see the cornerstone of Buddhism in this story - the triumph of the human body and spirit over the hardships, vices and cravings. Only through excruciating training, meditation and effort one can achieve the inner peace and liberty, and become a true Buddha.
The episode also contains a story of a little child, brought and abandoned by his mother. Spring comes again, and the monk becomes a Master, while the child is now an apprentice, and the cycle continues. The young boy learns how the world around him works and acquires life lessons from the Master, just as the Master did himself in his childhood. The goal of the Buddhist monks is to reach the nirvana - liberation from this endless cycle of lifetimes, but the central idea of the film is different - it shows that life never ends and goes in its own path like the seasons of nature.

Review_body:
This is an approximately two hours lasted film about a Buddhist monk and a child, who is being brought by the monk. From the first 5 minutes of watching, it can be ununderstood that the film is going to be mostly silent rather than wordy. Even though it has a few dialogues in it, those conversations were provided mostly in order to make the situation clear for the viewer and for a deeper understanding of the concept of the religion. From my point of view, the main ideas in the film are depicted in the actions and decisions of characters. The film was shot to deliver to people some of many concepts of Buddhism, such as Samsara, Reincarnation, and the four ideas, which are considered as fundamental ones in Mahayana.The concept of Samsara can be revealed straight away from the name of the movie - four seasons of nature flow one after another in repeating order. This concept demonstrates that no one has the ability to change this set of flow of nature and life.
Some of the Eightfold Noble Path is depicted in the Spring part of the movie. There displayed a monk and a boy, both of whom live in a pagoda on the lake. A man teaches the child to the core concepts of Buddhism. After that, there is a scene where the boy walks near a small pond and starts to mock a fish, a frog, and a snake, binding them with a stone. All of these antics were observed by a monk, who then decides to do the same with the boy in order to teach a lesson. A child finds out that it is painful and is told to free the animals. "If any of the animals died, you will forever have a stone in your heart," the monk added. The child goes back to the places where he found the animals. He cries because a snake and a fish are dead and buries them.
The Four Noble Truths are presented in the Summer part of the movie. The boy grows and becomes an adolescent. A woman addresses the monk due to the illness of her daughter. The young man sees such a beautiful girl for the first time. The mother leaves her daughter to be treated. The boy starts to look after the girl, and his feelings grow as time flows while the girls do not perceive his intentions. Two days later, she finally accepts his attention and does not resist anymore. This led to a sexual act between them. The monk notices everything, finds the girl cured, and tells the boy: "Lust awakens the desire to possess and that awakens the intent to murder", which matches with the content of the lecture "the root of sufferings are cravings (trishna)." Then the Master sends the girl back, for which the boy cannot stop to think about and decides to go after her.
In the Fall part of the movie, the monk gets old ages, and his pupil gets 30 years. One day the latter comes back to the Master to achieve Prajna and to hide away because he killed his beloved for some reason. The monk greets him with no bad flashbacks and talks to him in a positive manner. The pupil gets angry with himself and tries to commit suicide. The Master tells him it is impossible to kill yourself so effortlessly and makes him curve out the characters on the floor in order to drive out the anger from his heart. While doing that, two policemen appeared and wanted to arrest the criminal. Still, the Master stopped them because his pupil has to end the work began. The policemen understood and stayed in the pagoda until the pupil finishes. During the time spent there, all of those three ones became kinder, and on the other day, the pupil goes with the policemen without any enforcement. Later, having understood what are Shunyata, Prajna, Karuna, and Upaya, which are key concepts of Mahayana, the Master burns himself on the boat.
In the Winter part of the movie, the former criminal becomes a monk himself and stands on a halfway of understanding all of the abovementioned concepts. He returns to the pagoda and does the basic Buddhist rituals, thus continuing the previous pace of the life of his Master. He finds an old dictionary, where the basics of Yoga are demonstrated. Besides that, there are scenes where previously killed animals are living again. At the end of that part, an unknown woman comes to the pagoda and leaves her child to be raised by the monk.In the last part of the film, the wheel of Samsara closes. The child raises and does the same things that this monk did in his childhood.
Such a fascinating film made to think about life profoundly and from various perspectives. The concept that the life cycle never ends still does not leave me.
