Review_body:
The movie "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter, and... Spring" introduces the viewer to the Buddhist culture and traditions. Director used an interesting technique with transitions from one season to another, showing different stages of the life of a monk and a boy. Every season portrays a didactic lesson about Buddhism. The movie finishes with a similar scene from the beginning and suggests the continuation of the story. In addition, every season is replaced by the next in another year, showing the beginningless and endless chain of lifetime's continuation. Moreover, the actions in the second shown spring seem to be repeated with a slight plot change. It can suggest that the director wanted to show important religious concepts such as samsara, wheel of existence with the idea of anatman.
According to the belief that Buddha is nowhere and everywhere, the movie is full of symbols suggesting his presence, without him being anywhere. Nikolay Tsyrempilov, in the lecture "The early Buddhism" (Lecture, Nazarbayev University, January 25, 2021) suggests that Buddha statues, trees, and lions are symbols of Buddha. Some symbols of Buddha in the film are the tremendous statue of the Buddha at the edge of the forest, statues of lions on the floating temple, trees around the temple, and especially the one in the river. Regarding the main characters, as both of them are monks or in a state of becoming monks, they follow celibacy. It can be seen that they have dietary restrictions, live a non-violent life, meditate and pray a lot. Their heads are shaved, however, when the boy left the temple it can be seen that he had grown hair back. This can also be interpreted as a sign of him distancing from the religion for some period of time.
Dividing the film into semantic parts, it would be useful to analyze each season separately and note the Buddhist practices in each of the seasons. Firstly, as the movie starts with the spring, the movie narrates a story of an adult monk and a little boy. From the beginning, the movie introduces viewers to the concept of karma. For torturing animals little boy was punished by his master. As he was tying up substantially big stones to the animals, the master tied up a little boy's back big stone. He had to free the animals before he could be freed himself, and the responsibility for the death of the animals he had to carry as a burden in his heart. This way, the monk showed how karma works, and how every action has a repercussion.
The second part is about the same monk and a young pupil. The young guy who lives away from people, not familiar with sensual desires is faced with something new for the first time. A new concept of desires and cravings is presented in this part. Awakened lust made the young guy give up some principles of celibacy, as he had sexual intercourse with a girl, who came to get well. After the monk found out, he told a boy about desires and craving and their detrimental effect on life. This is a reference to the four noble truths, the basic formula of Buddhism (Tsyrempilov, " The early Buddhism", Nazarbayev University, January 25, 2021.) According to Trishna, the roots of all suffering are cravings, and later this backfired on the young guy. The season ended with the guy leaving the temple.
The next season is Fall. As monks don't earn subsistence but beg for food, already an old monk returned to the temple with food he was given. From the news, he found out that his former pupil committed a murder. As he was telling before "the desire to possess awakens the intent to murder". As a pupil returned, he was tortured by the mental sufferings. According to the duhkha, the first noble truth - life is full of suffering, both physical and mental. As the third noble truth states, to overcome sufferings one should overcome cravings. The scene of how a young pupil was etching the Pranja-parpamitasutra, shows the spectrum of his emotions and how he freed from anger. This practice demonstrates how religion helped the pupil to overcome desires take the path of religion firmly again. Also, it can be noticed that monks are highly respected in society. The police officers did not immediately detain the young guy at the request of the monk but gave him time to complete the religious practice. The season ended with the old monk's death. It worth noting that under the boat, where the monk died, the serpent appeared. It might be that reincarnation occurred and the stream of dharma took the form of a serpent.
Winter. Pupil returned to the floating temple. The idea that the serpent is reincarnated old monk, enhanced by the fact that the serpent was lying on the monk's left clothes. Moreover, throughout the season serpent was looking after the new monk. This might indicate the important aspect of the Mahayana Buddhists- bodhisattva. Sanghas' motivation other than to achieve Nirvana, is to help others to achieve enlightenment and become Buddha. Moreover, it can be seen that monk and his pupil, try to help other people in need. During the winter, a woman left her child in the monk's temple and the monk became a master for this child. After the winter, comes another spring and it indicates that the wheel of life continues.
In conclusion, the movie illustrates miscellaneous Buddhist practices and introduces various concepts. The film ends with the statue of Buddha looking down on everything. Again highlighting the idea of Buddha's ubiquity. Even the person, who is not familiar with the Buddhist traditions, can learn a lot after watching this film.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: It changed my viewpoint on life when I was 10. And it changed it again after 10 years
Review_body:
This masterpiece of Kim Kiduk lacks the dialogues. However, it is rich for symbolism and hidden messages, so dialogues seem unnecessary.
Film describes the fate of a child Buddhist monk disciple living in an isolated floating temple with his master. The painting on the side of the boat representing the lotus birth of Buddha symbolizes the original purity of human mind at birth. As lotus blooms spotless clean in the mud so human is innocent when he is born. In this film you can see how child is influenced by different emotions as temptation, desire to possess and anger through his life, and how stages of this maturation is beautifully aligned with the seasons of a year.(SPOILER ALERT)
SpringSpring symbolizes the beginning of a new life. As the new sprouts appear, they seem tender and inexperienced. You can see how the older generation teaches the younger their wisdom and knowledge.
One interesting detail are 'useless' doors inside the temple. They divide the room into 3 distinct area, yet there is no real wall. Despite that both monk and his disciple use doors instead of bypassing it. I guess it is made for self-discipline: to follow the rules that master set despite how ridiculous it seems.
Also, the biggest message in this part is a first point in a Buddhist code of behavior: "Refrain from harming living being". Master punishes his disciple the same way as he tortured the animals so he could feel what he did and warns him: "If one of them dies you will carry the rock in your heart for the rest of your life".SummerSummer is often associated with youth, freedom, and pleasure.
We can notice the symbolism of the doors once again here. As he becomes more tempted with desires, he breaks the habit of using the doors. When he crawls to the girl he steps over his master and avoids both doors. There was no actual prohibition for any kind of action, no matter if it is a lust or crime. 'Door' gives you a choice if you want to take that action or not, but once those 'doors' fall you will stop being conscious about those choices.
As monk learns about the relationships between his disciple and the guest, he says that it is natural. However, he sends the guest back to her home as "lust awakens the desire to possess, and that awakens the intent to murder". But doors have already fallen for the disciple and he leaves following his desires.FallFall is a decline of life when nature goes to its 'death'.
The disciple is also in the lowest point of his life. Full of anger and rage, after revenging his unfaithful wife, he comes back to the temple.
He feels lost, his mind is not peaceful, and he feels like he has no control over himself. Sealing his eyes, mouth, and ears with a character 'Close' he possibly wanted to abstract away and remove all the senses. His master makes him to carve the heart sutra on a wooden floor using a weapon, with which he committed a murder to bring the peace to his heart back. The frame where the monk hits the can with a rock that detectives could not shoot shows the high level of self-control and mindfulness. After the disciple finishes carving, he seems to regain the peace in his mind.
Fall represents the down of the monk's life too. The snake swimming away the boat after monk's death may mean the transmigration of his soul and rebirth.
You see the snakes a lot throughout the film. Master warns the boy about abundance of snakes in the beginning of the movie, boy kills the snake, he notices the mating snakes in his adolescence, the monk's soul transmigrates into the snake. It may be the referral to the Nagi, the divine creatures from the Buddhist mythology.WinterWinter represents the death and still life. As the disciple comes back to the temple he founds it in abandoned state and learns about the death of his master. He collects the Sarira of his master and places into the ice Buddha statue as a relic.
Another meaning of the winter is a confrontation. Harsh weather tempers the mind and raises the resilience. He starts the confrontation the 'evil' in himself trying to temper both his body and mind. He still 'carries the rock in his heart' from his past actions and he is mindful about it. Meanwhile another person could not confront the 'harsh winter' in her life and leaves her baby to the monk.and... SpringLife is cyclic. This is a law of samsara.
As seasons of the year replaces each other there is a younger generation that replaces the older ones.
Peace came to the life of the monk as spring relived the nature after the long winter. There is a new sprout that is just developing his buds. And he is yet to learn about life around him, about violence, about love, about temptations and desires. And he is yet to carry his own rocks in his heart.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
Kim Ki-duk directed the South Korean film "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter, and... Spring" in 2003. The film tells a story of a Buddhist monk and his apprentice, who live in the lake's floating temple. As the Buddhist disciple grows, he faces various challenges on his way. However, according to the Buddhist teachings, existence is not a linear or transient entity; it is a cycle of life, death, and rebirth, accompanied by suffering. This philosophy serves as a framework of the character's path: the cycle will resume at the very end. Despite the peaceful setting of an isolated forest with picturesque views and a light tone of the initial minutes, the film raises complicated, even intricate, yet compelling questions about life, death, and everything in-between. However, what makes this film an outstanding example of visual art is excellent storytelling and the combination of symbolism, paradoxes in Buddhism, and perhaps the inexplicable tranquility even during the tensest episodes. This review will attempt to present a novel viewpoint about the film, namely, that the film's central idea revolves around the blurred boundaries between various ideas relating to human existence: innocence and cruelty; love and lust; the sacred and the secular.The film's first scene depicts the opening gates that are not attached to any walls (Kim, 2003, 0:01:28). The gates are freestanding and serve as a barrier between the lake with the temple and the rest of the world. There is no indication of a person who opened them, and throughout the film, there will be times when the gates will magically open or close by themselves. However, such instances will not necessarily stand out and be easily spotted. Somehow, this particular magical element is embedded into the reality of the film. These gates illustrate the first example of a blurred boundary between the spiritual-magical world and the profane reality. The temple is not enclosed, not physically separated from the forest, there is no fence, yet all the film characters abide by the unspoken rule - every time they want to go to the temple or see the master, they go only through the gate.
The film proceeds to a significant example, which will set the tone for the unfolding events later in the film. Sometimes it is hard to distinguish between the poisonous herb and the one that can heal the sick. How can one tell the difference if they look almost identical? "Look closely. Here at the tip, you can see a white line" says the master to his apprentice (Kim, 2003, 0:08:47). It is notable how easily the master spots the poisonous herb and throws it away. The apprentice observes and then light-heartedly asks, picking another bundle: "Is this one alright to eat?" (Kim, 2003, 0:09:02). The young apprentice has a lot to learn, but the master is patient and is willing to teach him everything he knows. Although the herbs will not be mentioned anymore later, this example prepares viewers for deeper insights and acts as a precursor for further questions.Moreover, it touches upon one of the fundamental concepts in Buddhism - suffering. The painful death would have been inevitable if not for the knowledge and attentiveness of the master. Once again, signifying the blurring between two closely related concepts.Keeping in mind the herbs' lesson, the young apprentice plays with the dog and the next day goes to the forest to play with other animals. First the fish, then the frog and the snake - all of them were tied to a stone one after another - such an amusing entertainment for the young disciple. The viewer might even forget that it is no longer an innocent game; it is cruel or even torturous. One can wonder how the young apprentice did not know the difference between those two, but the earlier example with herbs showed the boy's indifference and absentmindedness in the face of such decisions. The boy can neither differentiate between a poisonous herb and medicinal herb nor between game and violence. That is why the young apprentice will carry the stone in his heart for the rest of his life. A small mistake will transform into a heavy burden.Finally, the film presents the blurriest border of all - the one between love and lust. Love heals the sick, as the master put it, it can be the "right medicine" (Kim, 2003, 0:47:27). However, it is not valid on all occasions, as under the influence of love, person's mind can be clouded, and one will not notice how love will transform into lust and the desire to possess. According to the Buddha's Four Noble Truths, there is a cause of suffering, which lies in the attachment. Indeed, the disciple will eventually acknowledge his feelings to the young girl and run away, succumbing to his feelings. The disciple will not try to end suffering, and he will fall into the trap of killing his wife at the end. Only after violating the first of the Five Precepts (Do not kill) will the disciple return to the "right" path.Eventually, the master will die, leaving the temple behind, and his disciple will take his place after returning from prison. The disciple becomes the master, and there will be another young apprentice. The cycle continues; however, some of the questions are yet to be answered. Will they make the same mistakes all over again? Will there be the same amount of suffering, or is there hope? Will the master teach the apprentice the blurred boundaries of human existence? However, one thing is clear: just as the gates with no walls secure the spiritual world from the profane reality, the blurred boundaries will persist.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: This is the story of life.
Review_body: When I plan to see a movie, I usually choose a fun and simple one. Besides I don't see the same movie again even though it is very amusing. However this film is totally different from the other ones I have watched. It tells me a story about 'a person's normal life', a part of nature, and makes me reflect on my life. Just like a fairy tale Grandmother tells me, I never feel sick and tired of this movie no matter how many times I see it. While I am watching the movie, I feel as if I were in it and I contemplate my life, not the monk's life (main character), in a serene state of mind.The story starts off as 'spring', symbolizing 'an early years of life', and an old monk's (Yeong-su Oh) leading a child one (Jong-ho Kim) to a right direction. He then becomes a young man (Jae-kyeong Seo) who is interested in girls and he falls in love with a beautiful girl (Yeo-jin Ha) who visits his place. Finally he leaves the temple looking for her. After committing a terrible murder, he (Young-min Kim) returns to the temple but is arrested. When he (Ki-duk Kim) comes back to the temple after being released from prison, he finds that his teacher monk is already dead. One day a baby comes there and again spring begins.Unlike many other movies, this movie expresses what it wants to say by showing the changes of seasons and not excessive acting rather than many lines between characters. Amazing cinematography made me feel like I was admiring oriental paintings throughout the film. The smooth and peaceful changes of the seasons showed a humans' whole life and the lake surrounding round the temple also made a perfect match. Especially, along with nature giving a silent lesson, the old monk's teaching was very touching because he usually waited for the younger monk to get spiritual enlightenment by himself. It seemed that this movie tried to show that humans experience birth, love, lust, pain, jealousy, despair, death and rebirth as nature is constantly changing. I can't help saying the exquisite and harmonious landscape of the temple, the lake and colors of seasons is the piece de resistance.The plot in this movie was more of a narrative structure. As time flowed away together with a change of season, the young main character experienced a checkered life. The development of the plot was shown through the change of the scenery around the floating temple. Spring full of vividness, summer of lust, fall - the season of harvest, and winter of loneliness and beauty are humans' normal lives.The music in this film also played the similar role to dialog. Thus, even when actors didn't express any feelings or emotion with dialog, music said more than words. The music without too high or too low pitch like natural sounds and Korean traditional music, 'Arirang,' touched something deep in my heart and illuminated my life.Finally, my favorite things about this movie are the doors as a gate and in the temple . The doors had no walls so we could look inside from both sides of the doors even though the doors were closed. The old monk and the young one always used the doors, not the passage of its sides but when the young monk couldn't curb his lust for a girl, he used the side passage. It meant he couldn't control himself.Most people do not live as a monk, so the whole plot may seem to be unrealistic and very far-fetched but this movie illuminates humans' innermost problems, not two monks' lives. To anyone who goes through difficulties in their lives or wants to find comfort in something, I highly recommend seeing this film again and again.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: The Arbitrariness and Absolute Necessity of Doorways
Review_body: This movie alone challenged my interpretation of film; basically the very fundamental framework of film-making -- the aperture -- is itself a doorway to the experience of film, a meta-language within the common visual dialect, and now thanks to Ki-Duk Kim's gentle tutelage, it illuminates an understanding of the harrowing and impossible role of the subjective experience in the grander scheme of the nature of this world we inhabit.Ki-Duk Kim's stage in this piece of illustrative theater, a floating monastery, is itself a 1.66:1 framework, first framed by the 1.33:1 of an ornate gate which reveals the stage framed in the grander and somehow less accessible (and impossibly fractal) proscenium of lake-tree- mountain-sky.Thus Ki-Duk tells us within the first 2 minutes that beauty is the intractable edge between nature and sentience; while many have seen this as a "morality play" or a "Buddhist parable" of the evils of attachment and desire, we are quickly assured (and sometimes even jarringly corrected) that oftentimes morality as we view it -- with its opinions, its judgments of good and evil -- is really itself a distraction. In its place -- a rare commodity it seems -- simple empathy will suffice; empathy say with a fish tied to a rock.But alas, this state of a simple empathic morality cannot be sustained. In the western culture, we are familiar with a fall from grace -- it's parallel in the Ki-Duk universe is the awakening of desire that all sentient beings must encounter. For instance, the old monk does not chide his pupil for succumbing to his temptation; instead he plays a silly trick (one that indeed gives me a chilling flashback to Peter Greenaway's "Drowning By Numbers". In fact, I could not flee the fear of submersion and drowning which permeates this film, nor could I cast away the similarities between Ki-Duk Kim's and Greenaway's early -- i.e. not composited -- visual storytelling).The old monk is not at all moralistic about desire and its fulfillment -- he admits that it has healing purposes. He is clear, however, that desire as natural as it is, leads to possessiveness which leads to murder. Desire, because of its selfish possessive nature, precludes empathy, and thus leads to "murder" whether literal or allegorical (in order to live we must make others suffer).This film touches many more facets of human existence -- repentance, the inescapable cyclical nature of time, simple compassion in the face of personal hopelessness. In addition, it challenges our understanding of film -- both in its manufacture and consumption. At what point does the framing of the narrative become observable; which framing is intended, and which framing do we bring to our observation of it?
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: This film bored me all the way through. It was a bit like watching a beautiful documentary of a small family living in hut on a lake in Tibet. But, somebody hit the mute button and I'm too lazy to get the remote. So, I'm left to imagine what I'm supposed to be getting out of this movie with my ample time between interesting events and/or plot progression.Imagery yes, story no. It was very Buddhist, but that is all. The plot moved at a snail's pace. The movie went mostly without dialog. It was like a 15 minute comic book had been turned into a full-length movie.All picture no plot. Not as offensive as Twilight though.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: This is the only film I've seen by this director, so I can't compare this film with his others. "Spring, Summer..." is a moral tale--somewhat simplistic, but nevertheless effective. It's a film that never ends. I say this because the movie merely illustrates one link in an eternal tale (this is suggested by the end). One belief in Buddhism is of "eternal recurrence." Karma. It's also of a man who pains himself to seek to rectify his mistakes, his selfishness, his egotism. This in turns produces a much needed balance in his life.I do wonder about one thing: I thought Buddhist monks were forbidden to touch women. Is this not so in Korea?
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: This movie keeps taking surprising turns, and whenever you think you've got it figured out, it changes again. It tries to show how craving for sensory pleasures will ultimately, and inevitably, bring you suffering. Everything, and everyone, comes to an end. Knowing nothing about the film beforehand certainly helped me keep a rather naive state of mind throughout, much like the boy in the movie itself, so you might not be as surprised as I was at the turn of events. However, this movie will definitely make you think about life. If you're into Buddhism, it's spot on. If not, you'll still be able to find a lot of interesting points being made. Each season shows a different part of their lives, and even a different degree of suffering. It's not as gloomy as it sounds, though. I found a lot of positive energy in it, as well as charm and humour. Don't miss this movie!
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: Visually beautiful and quietly wise!! I like movies that offer me a different kind of experience, an occasion to ponder, and a topic to discuss with others. This unexpected gem of a movie met all these criteria of a worthwhile film.  Watching this film was more than just a movie-going experience, it was an enlightenment, a meditation, an experience on an epic scale. Simplicity, beauty, and genius describe the work. You fall into it, experience it, and resurface somewhat differently than how you had fallen in. If you want to experience a film so profound and exotic yet so basic and naked, I recommend this film wholeheartedly. You will be subtlely captured.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
I did not read to much into the symbols and rather just appreciated the movie for what it was. Beautiful in it's cinematography, and it spoke to me on a personal level at the time I watched it.
Not sure if I would recommend it to everyone, but I - for one - did enjoy it very much.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: Last Saturday, I visited a movie theater in Bethesda to watch the Korean movie "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter ... And Spring." When "The Passion of The Christ" on Ash Wednesday was still lingering in my eyes, the new movie gave another uncommon impression.In the Mel Gibson's film, I ruminated again the meaning of Jesus Christ's redemption on behalf of mankind, from the story where he was born of the Mary, suffered under Pontius Pilate, was crucified, and died. Thus the movie just visually intensified the familiar story from the bible, Good Friday's passion play, or J.S. Bach's passion music.On the other hand, what is the meaning of the Kim KiDuk's movie occurring in a small temple on the tranquil waters of a pond? The movie does not give any clear conclusion like rewarding the good and punishing the wicked. Instead, rather vague ending becomes the topic of meditation for the audience.Based on private analysis from the viewpoint of Buddihism, the movie teaches the lesson that you should not do any bad action which causes negative karma in transmigrating world.Spring anticipates summer, summer does autumn, autumn does winter, and winter repeatedly does spring. In this circulative nature, one human, as a part of nature, sometimes gets pleasure in bothering others. In the movie, a boy monk takes pleasure in tying animals with a heavy pebble. This misconduct which deprived animals' lives is subject to boomerang. However, the chief monk who wants to prevent the nemesis sacrifices himself by cremation and the boy monk is born again to live another new life.Likewise, does our evil conduct to others or destruction to nature become a bad karma? While Christianity teaches that whoever repents and believes in Jesus can be forgiven and go to heaven, Buddhism says that as a man sows so he shall reap in the life to come. This also seems to become the major lesson of this film.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: It is rare today to be able to find a movie that is not only emotionally moving, but is also so very spiritually insightful. I only know a little about Buddhism (and being more familiar with its religious details would have made my experience even more meaningful, I'm sure), but something inside of me resonated as I followed the life of the two primary characters, watching them handle everyday human experiences and knowing in my own heart the universal struggles they were facing. I have never, that I remember, left a theater feeling as much at peace about life as I did after I saw this film. The scenery, characters, and life principles are all worth meditating on.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: This is probably the best movie ever made. The humanity and drama of it is profound. This is by far my favorite movie. Kim Ki-Duk is a self-taught master. The visuals and sound, including ambient noise and the flow of dialogue are some of the most peaceful and mesmorizing images you will see. The main theme of the song is fantastic. This is what movies are supposed to be, original, unique pieces of art. The man-made lake that this film was shot on is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen, and Kim Ki-Duk take full advantage of this setting. I do not speak Korean, and saw the movie with English subtitles (of which are few), I do not know if that takes away anything from the movie, though I am sure it does. What a sublime buddhist story. I highly recommend this movie.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: Pretty, well acted and nice movie
Review_body: A beautiful and thought provoking tale of desires, love and friendship. It is from a Buddhist perspective but everyone can learn something from this movie. It has some great moral teachings in it that makes this movie both deep and soothing at the same time. The story is easy to follow and is a beautiful story. The environment and scenes was absolutely stunning to look at and it made the movie so much better. Every frame is like a painting.But I have some negative opinions as well: A bit too slow pace for my taste therefore the 7/10.It follows the Zen school of Buddhism (maybe that is the reason the movie is slow) but the dramatic scenes is kind of boring. But this film is an nice,pretty and well acted movie. I absolutely think you should watch this movie.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: Nature has a nature to repeat itself.
Review_body: The plot of the movie revolves around an old monk (master) and a young monk (disciple), living on a floating house at an isolated lake.As we grow up, we go through certain changes at different stages of life. The movie has similarly depicted those changes, in a beautiful way of seasons. While the young monk grows up, he goes through various life learning experiences respective of his age and finally leave.The movie is about how our life goes on to have different seasons and don't end there. Nature repeats its seasons, year and year after. Likewise, the circle of life continues to have the same stages in a different form, through the following generations. Even if the monk was living isolated, oblivious of what in the rest of the world is going, he had to go through same seasons of life as we all do. Here, the thing to learn is that, irrespective of what our future generations will do, the basic human characters are always going to be there and repeat it as someone else.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: I like this movie.The scenes are REALLY beautiful. The story is simple and easy to be understood.In China, temples are usually in the mountains.But in this movie, the temple is in the middle of the lake, and it's FLOATING...As a Chinese, I didn't know that 般若波罗蜜多心经(prajna paramita sutra) in Korea is exactly the same as in China until I watch this movie.(same Chinese characters) Actually, It's so popular that many Hong Kong singers composed it(prajna paramita sutra)to make it a song sung in Cantonese. The words in sutra are very hard for ordinary people to understand.But due to the beautiful melody of the song, I can sing out every word of the sutra easily even though I don't know the meanings of the words in sutra .
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body: Perhaps the year 2000 heralded the inspirational decline at Hollywood and a new dawn in Asian cinema. "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring" is one of those movies that leads someone to this conclusion. Masterfully set amidst breathtaking landscapes, brilliantly inspired Ki-duk Kim manages to blend flawlessly the western central doctrine, expressed in Freud's theories, with the oriental belief in Karma leaving the viewer at the end with a strong taste of Heisenberg's principle of uncertainty. Kept simple, with few lines of dialog, the emphasis falls exclusively on the visual aspect. By using the symbolism of the collective unconscious, the movie challenges the beliefs of both oriental and western viewers in a subtle and elegant manner.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: This movie is a sumptuous feast for the eyes..
Review_body: ..but an appalling advertisement for Buddhism (and I am no Buddhist). There is much to enjoy in the superb visual richness of this film, but I was left deeply concerned about its presentation of Buddhist principles and practice. If you hope see a film about a novice Buddhist monk being taught the great mysteries, learning to respect all forms of life, and exploring the nature of cause and effect in dialogues with his 'master' you will be deeply disappointed. Instead viewers are privy to a few religious rituals that fail miserably in preparing a novice monk for a compassionate, wise or peaceful adult life. Time and time again in the movie the novice monk fails to relate compassionately to either himself or those about him, and there are several scenes of simple (but repeated and extended) cruelty which made me cringe as a human being.I found the various subtexts of the film (as I saw it) disturbing : that desire for sex (ie. desire for union of polarities & transcendence) is essentially a path that leads to suffering for all, and that the only way to find redemption for oneself is through time and ritual, rather than through practicing self-knowledge, kindness, and observing the nature of cause and effect.Ultimately I found this quite a depressing film about the potential of the human spirit. The message of the film, that human beings can_only_learn through suffering, worries me most. The movie begins and ends with a human being causing suffering to other sentient beings (admittedly through ignorance). That (to me) shows very little insight into the real beauty and essence of Buddhism, and it's also not very hopeful at all! After seeing this film I want to be a tree, for they have the most beautiful, untroubled existence in the film. The scenery in this movie merits much of my seven star rating.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: The "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter and ... Spring (2003)" is South Korean movie about inhabitants of the floating Buddhist monastery at the center of the lake.
Review_body:
Directed by Kim Ki-duk, and had a lot of positive reviews around the world. This movie tells the story of a person by showing the four seasons of his life which has changed him and taught the philosophy of the Buddhism from his childhood to the older ages. Throughout his life, the Master at the temple was his guide and influenced him. 
From the start of the movie, an everyday routine of Buddhist monks are shown. Throughout the film, the older master is a representation of a true Buddhist monk, whose views of the world differs from the boy's. He tries to teach the boy through the lesson about pain and guilt, cruel consequences of desire, releasing the anger and about reaching inner peace, but already without being beside. At the end, we can see that the little boy in the past became a master and from spring the cycle begins again with another little apprentice. Through this cycle, I understood that being a person with inner peace is not inborn, but reachable.
I want to talk about one interesting thing in this movie. The door which opens the view to the floating monastery, and another two doors in it are actually do not serve as simple doors continued with walls. They are standing alone and anyone could just walk around them. But, mostly people use them as actual doors that help us to enter certain place. Even in the monastery, people sleep behind the doors, open them to look at someone. In my point of view, walking through the door is an established tradition, while breaking this rule is going on a string of desire. I think this symbolizes the teenager, who made a decision in the wake of hormones, and had unexpected consequences.
I think the camerawork of this movie should be mentioned. Watching this movie was pleasure because of soft transitions between scenes and stable shooting. Also, cameraman showed the beautiful nature of that forest surrounding the lake and hills. When picture is enjoyable, perception of the movie is always better.
The quality of the sound was also good, though the film was shot in 2003. However, the musical accompaniment was not rich. Sometimes, the Buddhist music (?) or sounds come out, but basically they focused on life sounds. 
Ki-duk said of the film: "I intended to portray the joy, anger, sorrow and pleasure of our lives through four seasons and through the life of a monk who lives in a temple on Jusan Pond surrounded only by nature."
To sum up, I would like to say that this movie by Kim Ki-duk is very touching and realistic. All these teachings give an opportunity to all people to get to know with Buddhist religious traditions, philosophy and life of the monks. The story tells us that every monk become himself and reaches inner peace through experiencing and realizing the importance of it. But I think this can be related to anyone, despite the religion, nationality and gender.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: A beautiful and very simple allegory about thresholds we must overpass in life...
Review_body: This is the second film directed by Kim Ki-Duk that I saw. The first one was Bin-jip and I can say that I really like both of them.Despite the very long and difficult to remember title (Spring, summer, autumn, winter...and spring), in the final, seeing the film is a rewarding experience.First of all I love in this film the idea of an floating hermitage (monastery) in the middle of a lake. All the "action" (and there is little action, but more frames of action) takes place on this hermitage. In the beginning of the film there are only an old monk and a little boy (his protégé) in this monastery. Being surrounded by water gives the sensation of isolation from the outer world, a space of loneliness where man can resonate perfect with the nature. The door that opens at the beginning of each one of the five seasons could be interpreted as a gate, linking the two worlds: our world and their world. To go-in and go-out in the idyllic space where the hermitage floats every people must go through this gate.In fact the film is a very simple allegory about the cyclic evolving life. The beginning and the final of the film encloses a cycle: in the first season we find the old monk and the little boy; the boy grows-up, evolves, learns, suffers, loves, is punished and self-punishes him for his mistakes. After all these experiences the boy, an adult now, is capable to guide through life another human being. In winter he is the adult monk and he has a little boy as a protégé. And the cycle starts all over.Also the film is about the thresholds that we must overpass in our life from the childhood till the adulthood, and the fact that these thresholds are very similar for all of us.Allover the movie there are very subtle Buddhist symbols like the five animals (a dog, a rooster, a cat, a snake and finally a turtle) each one of them being associated with one season.The film is a superbly visual experience and has a musical theme that repeats in the beginning of each of the five seasons creating (for me at least) a dreaming sensation.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review title: Paints a picture of life.. i guess
Review_body: This movie just got way too dark and disturbing for me. Such is life however, moments of happiness and moments of pain and suffering. Does its job of driving home the Buddhist view on life as well as cycles and the seasons. There are things to be learned from this film.

Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
"Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter...and Spring" is a breathtaking and fascinating movie that tells a story of a Buddhist monk and his disciple. A perfectly shot masterpiece that ideally transfers emotions and ideas through carefully constructed dialogues, scenes and music. 
The film is a representation of a never-ending cycle of life shown through the struggles of the Master and his disciple. Beginning with the disciple's early life and his education, moving on to his first love and unbearable struggles of love that further resulted in a murder, flowing into the death of the Master and ultimately ending with the disciple becoming a master himself. Only in "again Spring" a viewer may notice the same pattern of human behavior, whereby "lust awakens the desire to possess, and that awakens the intent to murder". 
And the movie shows the aforementioned lesson not only on the example of innocent animals, but on the example of relationships as well. The disciple's lust and desire to possess led him to a murder of his wife, after she decided to leave him. Therefore, the movie gives a fundamental philosophical lesson of too much emotions leading to catastrophic results. 
Despite this critical lesson, the movie ends with another one: life is a never-ending cycle of people constantly making mistakes and learning. On the example of the disciple, we see growth of a person, more precisely spiritual growth. Where a person surrendered to lust and murder learned his mistakes and ultimately became a monk and a master to a boy. Another example is the 'new' disciple, a boy who just as his 'new' master harms animals resulting in their death. Hence, just as the name of the movie, this film symbolizes the cycle of life with constant mistakes and lessons. 
Another major detail to be mentioned is the deeper Buddhist philosophy shown in the film, particularly philosophy of Mahayana branch. For Mahayana Buddhists, Arhats (advanced disciples of Buddha) are those that help others attain nirvana, or in other words social workers of Buddha. Mahayana Buddhists also believed that every individual is able to attain nirvana with the help of Arhats. Philosophy shown in this movie resembles that of Mahayana, whereby the master represents an Arhat and his disciple being an ordinary individual in the very beginning, attaining nirvana during 'Winter' and becoming a master to another boy in 'again Spring'. With the cycle, this movie also shows philosophy very much similar to that of Mahayana Buddhists'. 
One more important message that one might interpret having watched this film is the law of cause and effect, or in other words 'what goes around comes back around' law. The law of karma, if you wish, is represented throughout the whole movie, beginning with the master giving a hot and strong lesson to his disciple ending with the new disciple making the same mistakes just as his 'new' master did before. This yet another important lesson is beautifully and masterfully represented throughout the movie teaching its viewers one more crucial lesson of philosophy of life. 
One of the most beautiful and meaningful things about this movie that I would like to mention is the scene of the temple flowing around the lake. The rapidly shot scene is meant to represent the pace of life, more precisely the swiftness of the cycle of life. This peculiar scene reminded me of the importance of life joy. In the rushing pace of today's world people often forget to enjoy and cherish little things in their life. In the rush for a successful career, houses, cars, people become blind to what they already possess. To avoid this issue, I find this scene to be a great reminder of how fast-going life is and how important it is to dedicate yourself to truly important things. Material possessions come and go while inner peace is difficult to obtain. 
With regards to cinematography of the film it is undoubtedly a masterpiece. The simplicity of the movie is stunning, with short yet deep dialogues, beautiful scenes and perfectly selected music to accompany all of the goodness. Ki-duk Kim performed a masterful job leaving his viewers with a beautifully shot movie and a thousand lessons to learn.
Movie_name: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring

Review_body:
How many at the same time silent and simple movies did you watch, so that you got a great feelings and deep thought about the meaning of our life in this world? I will venture to assume that you can mention only a couple of movies you remember, if any. How a silent and simple movie can be a philosophical and give a food for deep thoughts about the existence of the human being? Isn't it intriguing? If not, you definitely should watch this movie, as it offers so many emotions and makes you think, although, the film is not completely silent, and it has some occasional dialogues, still, they are so rare that you will not realize much difference between totally silent movies and this one. What is more, the movie is full of metaphors, a feature which can often be found in other Korean movies. Even the title of film is itself a metaphor, referring to the five stages of the human being. The movie starts with the spring, and it is a first phase of the human, a childhood, warm and cheerful period. Main characters are old monk and young boy, who live in a hut and follow the day-to-day duties and strict discipline of the Buddhist religion. Every attribute of the hut demonstrates the total adherence of the old and wise monk and young boy to the religion. For instance, doors in the hut and by lakeside are illustrated as a symbolic rather than prescriptive, demonstrating the discipline. On the other hand, hut plays the role of a self, which controls our mind and body in conscious condition. When a person is out of self, he commits a crime and does bad things, same as with hut, when young boy killed frog and snake when he was out of the hut. 
When comes a summer, an energetic and romantic period of the human, a youth, a young sick girl comes to the hut of grown up boy and monk to get a help of the Buddha and get rid of the heaviness in her soul. This season is illustrated with the period, when boy recognizes his lust and falls in love, and consequently do mistakes, which will cost his future. Here, doors are again given as a symbol of the discipline, which a boy brakes first time crossing the imaginable wall past the door in the night to lie down next to a young girl. Afterwards, a boy makes a critical choice to leave the hut to follow that young girl, symbolically leaving his self, and it will determine and change rest of his years. 
The next stage of the human development is demonstrated in the form of autumn, depressed and bewildered after the continuous search of short-term enjoyment and pleasure, a maturity. A boy is now an adult man, who became a wiser enough person to understand his lifechanging decisions, and tries to get back to his hut, to his self, and restore everything. However, he struggles to solve his problems, which remind him a choice he made in his youth every day as a nightmare. At the end of the season he ends up suffering a penalty for his wrong deeds.
Winter, which is cold and calm, refers to the advanced age of the person. He incurred a punishment, and he is now old and wise, as was old monk in his childhood. He reached a stage, when he is conscious enough to return to his roots, his self, and to his hut. And he returns to his symbolic hut and continues the old ceremonies, which he learned in his early childhood. Interesting moment here is that a wild snake, which was a victim of a man when he was a young boy, becomes a "pet" in the hut, while old monk had different but more domestic pets in each season, including cock, and cat. Moreover, man becomes the reason of another death of human completely unintentionally. All of these symbolize a karma, a spiritual principle of cause and effect in Buddhist religion. 
The last period of the human is illustrated as a spring, again warm and cheerful period. New born baby grows up to a young boy and becomes the mate of the man, and follower of the Buddhist religion, identically, as in his own childhood. Interestingly, the actors, which play both children are a one person, thus symbolizing the idea that life is eternal. Another metaphor, which was one of the most powerful ones in this movie is the game of a new child, who plays the same game of killing symbolically the same animals: frog, snake, and fish. It again reminds us about the karma, that everything what we do in our lives returns to us soon or later. 
In general, although movie does not have many dialogues and very simple in action, and even frank in some moments, it gives lots of emotions and makes to meditate for a moment about our life, our decisions, and our consciousness.
